To make contact (with) while in proximity.
To come face to face with by accident; to encounter.

senses.sense: To come face to face with someone by arrangement.
examples: Let's meet at the station at 9 o'clock.

senses.sense: To get acquainted with someone.
examples: I'm pleased to meet you! I'd like you to meet a colleague of mine.
I met my husband through a mutual friend at a party. It wasn't love at first sight; in fact, we couldn't stand each other at first!

senses.sense: (Of groups) To come together.
To gather for a formal or social discussion; to hold a meeting.
examples: I met with them several times. The government ministers met today to start the negotiations.

senses.sense: To come together in conflict.
(sports) To play a match.
examples: England and Holland will meet in the final.

senses.sense: To make physical or perceptual contact.
To converge and finally touch or intersect.
examples: The two streets meet at a crossroad half a mile away.

senses.sense: To touch or hit something while moving.
examples: The right wing of the car met the column in the garage, leaving a dent.

senses.sense: To adjoin, be physically touching.
examples: The carpet meets the wall at this side of the room. The forest meets the sea along this part of the coast.

senses.sense: (transitive) To respond to (an argument etc.) with something equally convincing; to refute.
examples: He met every objection to the trip with another reason I should go.

senses.sense: To satisfy; to comply with.
examples: This proposal meets my requirements. The company agrees to meet the cost of any repairs.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To balance or come out correct.
To perceive; to come to a knowledge of; to have personal acquaintance with; to experience; to suffer.
examples: The eye met a horrid sight. He met his fate.

(Judaism, and occasionally Christianity) A piece of parchment inscribed with specific Hebrew verses from the Torah (Deuteronomy 6:4–9 and 11:13–21) and attached in a case to the doorpost of a house, in accordance with the mitzvah (Biblical commandment as interpreted in Jewish law) to "write the words of God on the gates and doorposts of your house" (Deuteronomy 6:9).

(architectural element) An intermediate floor or storey in between the main floors of a building; specifically, one that is directly above the ground floor which does not extend over the whole floorspace of the building, and so resembles a large balcony overlooking the ground floor; an entresol.
examples: On our way to the top floor, we stopped at the mezzanine.

senses.sense: (architectural element) (by extension) An apartment, room, etc., on such an intermediate floor.
(architectural element) (Canada, US) The lowest balcony in an auditorium, cinema, theatre, etc.; the dress circle.
(architectural element) (obsolete) Additional flooring laid over a floor to bring it up to some height or level.
(architectural element) (obsolete) In full mezzanine window: a small window at the height of a mezzanine floor (sense 1.1) or an attic, used to light these floors.
(theater, obsolete) A floor under the stage, from which contrivances such as traps are worked.
(banking, business) Characteristic of or relating to high-interest loans which have no collateral, and are regarded as intermediate in nature, ranking above equity but below secured loans.
(engineering) Fulfilling an intermediate or secondary function.
examples: To make interconnections easier, we added a mezzanine PCB.

senses.sense: (transitive) To fit (a building or other place) with a mezzanine floor.
